channel.title: Release on Aperspection

item.title: Space Code E
item.description:
Space Code E is a continuation of the Space Codes series. It’s 60 minutes long, and is meant to help you focus on tasks like coding.

item.title: Teasers
item.description:
Teasers is a collection of quick tracks that I felt were blooming into something great, but never got the chance to fully finish. Or, they just didn’t need to be any longer and fulfilled their purpose.

My personal favorite is Crowdshock.

item.title: Space Codes
item.description:
Space Codes consists of 3 60-minute tracks that are meant to help you focus.

Each song in the release follows a similar repetitive pattern with variance over the span of each hour-long listen. The songs are meant to become background noise, with the intention of helping you reach higher productivity every time you need to sit down and focus.

I have a few songs that I often listen to on Spotify that are long:

  • Cosmoscope by au5
  • Solar One by The Flashbulb

I’ve found that these songs really help me get into a specific mindset, especially for focusing. I wanted to take this and give it back to the world with some of my own long-play songs.

By the way, Space Code D was supposed to be Space Code C, but there was a failure that occurred during upload/processing and I had to iterate the name.

Song Links

  • Spotify Album Link

More

  • Space Code C has been released.

item.title: Journeys
item.description:
Journeys is a collection of songs from the years 2012-2014. Taking a very different tone from the usual electronic music signature of Aperspection (such as from the previous album, Depthseeker), Journeys uses more realistic instruments in all of its songs, while still blending in electronic elements throughout. Some songs are especially heavy in creating a special ambiance.

Attributions

Many of the ambient sounds used in this album come from freesound.org. You can see a listing of every song I’ve used here - most notably, the ambient sounds used in Silent Chill (and the short version) and Utopia come from there. Thanks to all of the kind people on the site who are willing to let the world use their sounds for good.

Album links

  • Depthseeker Spotify album link -Apple Music/iTunes

Track list

  • Utopia
  • This Statement Is False
  • Sublime
  • Psychno
  • Undercover Coffee Shop

  • Ravine
  • Forest Rain
  • Vengeance

item.title: This Is Not My Homework
item.description:
Written around 2014 while attending university and putting off some upcoming homework assignments, This Is Not My Homework is a track with a bit more of an edge. I was experimenting with making bigger bass sounds and this is the result.

  • Spotify Direct link
  • YouTube
  • Apple Music/iTunes

item.title: Oceana
item.description:
The track Oceana was written in 2012. Oceana has a very relaxed, beach-like feel to it.

Released initially on iTunes (and a few other stores including Spotify) back around 2014, I had to take it down after it was up for a year. Now, fast forward to 2021, 9 years since its inception - we can hear it again.

The Radio Edit is a slightly shortened version.

  • Spotify link
  • The song has a surprising amount of Shazams.

item.title: Sessel
item.description:
Sessel is a song takes a lot of inspiration from uplifting trance.. The song’s strength is in the foundation - the moving piano strokes with the simple, yet strong chord progression allows a nice, smooth flow into a relaxed break in the middle of the song, followed by a build-up into a more elated and aggressive peak at the end.

  • Spotify
  • Apple Music/iTunes

item.title: Seasons
item.description:
Seasons is an aggressive, 140-bpm, uplifting, melodic trance tune that takes listeners on a journey through the four seasons, starting from fall and ending in summer.

Trained music producers will note the challenges faced with the audio compression and mixing. This song came about from some extra creativity that occurred while between classes in college - I had just purchased a copy of Sylenth1 and had to experiment with it.

  • Spotify
  • Apple Music/iTunes

item.description:

item.title: Skywind
item.description:
Skywind an EDM trance track took around 40 hours to produce. I spent a lot of time experimenting with getting various percussive and synth dynamics right.

Each of the “Edit” variants is mostly the same, with a few tweaks. These versions can never be re-created again due to loss of source material, so I uploaded them.

Album links

  • Spotify album link

Track list

Contains direct links to Spotify tracks.

  • Skywind
  • Skywind - Edit
  • Skywind - Melodic Edit

item.title: Desolate Paradigm
item.description:
Desolate Paradigm is a single with a more deep, chill style. The Submerged Edit has an even deeper feel.

item.title: Reflex
item.description:
Reflex is my personal favorite. It is a more abstract style of music that doesn’t really follow most patterns, and is inspired by Flume and Jon Hopkins.

The Extended Edit is actually an earlier version of the track that is not mixed as well, but contains a more cinematic introduction.

Album links

  • Spotify album link

Track list

Contains direct links to Spotify tracks.

  • Reflex
  • Reflex - Extended Edit

item.title: The Great Discovery
item.description:
The Great Discovery is another personal favorite.

The three edited versions were variations on the original theme that I enjoyed and wanted to share.

Album links

  • Spotify album link

Track list

Contains direct links to Spotify tracks.

  • The Great Discovery
  • The Great Discovery - Clean Climax Edit
    • The Clean Climax edit was an earlier version that does not contain the extra synth heard in the climax, but lacks some polish.
  • The Great Discovery - No Syncopation Edit
    • A significantly earlier version of the track. I originally did it in a 4/4 time signature, heard in this version.
  • The Great Discovery - Downshift Experimental Edit
    • The same as The Great Discovery, but pitch-shifted to have a different rhythm.

item.title: Out There
item.description:
Out There has a different vibe from most songs.

The three edited versions were variations on the original theme:

  • Two trap-styled edits.
  • The No Ambient Vocals Edit is actually the final version of the track and contains better mixing, but after hearing it a few years later, I preferred the current version of Out There.

Album links

  • Spotify album link

Track list

Contains direct links to Spotify tracks.

  • Out There
  • Out There - No Ambient Vocals Edit
  • Out There - Trap Mix
  • Out There - Trap Mix Edit

item.title: Ascending
item.description:
Ascending consists of two tracks that both have a climactic build-up over the duration of the song.

The Spooky Climax Edit is basically the same song, except for the final climax, and it is a bit of a joke - I was having some fun with dubstep and it ended up sounding like it belonged in some sort of halloween-styled track.

Album links

  • Spotify album link

Track list

Contains direct links to Spotify tracks.

  • Ascending
  • Ascending - Spooky Climax Edit

item.title: She Sings Colors
item.description:
She Sings Colors consists of two tracks. I created the original track as a draft, and a friend heard it and wanted to collaborate on it. We sent a few versions back and forth, but did not land on a finished result. The DSE edit is the last draft.

As for the song itself, it is inspired by drum and bass but doesn’t follow the typical genre. It features more powerful EDM-like saw synths with an uplifting chord progression. I found it difficult to bring the song to fruition amidst my college studies, and still consider it largely unfinished to date.

Album links

  • Spotify album link

Track list

Contains direct links to Spotify tracks.

  • She Sings Colors
  • She Sings Colors - DSE Edit
